Author: jaxxxxxxyyyy
Content: To start off, as a bimbel teacher myself, I would pointed out our education. There is a mismatch between our education and the job market. Vocational and higher education often don‚Äôt match the skills industries need in Indonesia. This is combined with the fact that many graduates lack critical thinking, digital skills, or practical experience. As a result, we are potentially being gifted with educated unemployment or underemployment in informal sectors. Then for job creations, most of these new jobs come from low-productivity sectors (agriculture, retail, informal services, etc). Meanwhile industrial and more advanced jobs are not following the same amount of job creations. The government further lacks strategic incentives to retain or attract talent, especially in research, R&D, or creative industries. This is just naming a few problems that the government didn't do to solve it.

Author: unknownblue
Content:
Indonesia‚Äôs bonus demography is not only underused‚ÄîI think it has even become a burden nowadays.

Although Indonesia has the assets and potential to develop further as a country because of our citizens as a whole, we have to admit that there is a massive brain drain. Why?

The supposed brightest of the bunch‚Äîthe cream of the crop‚Äîfor Indonesia would rather be working abroad. To be honest, it‚Äôs an obvious choice: the pay is better, infrastructure is better, welfare is better, and most importantly, they are acknowledged based on their merit.

And then we have the second problem, which is that a lot of individuals, especially youth, are unemployed‚Äînot to mention those who are still in the working age and remain unemployed.

Now we talk about wealth disparity as another reason.

The upper-middle class and higher economic families and individuals are able to access so much information and so many opportunities compared to those from middle- and lower-income backgrounds.

The middle-income individuals do not qualify to receive educational or economic assistance because they‚Äôre not considered poor.

The poor lack proper infrastructure that would support their growth with the substance or knowledge that they receive. It‚Äôs like giving a fishing boat to someone who has never fished and doesn‚Äôt even have a fishing pole.

Author: unknownblue
Content:
Now our government has done a few things here for the short term we actually implemented a really excellent program ‚Äú prakerja‚Äù 

The program is excellent by so many measures and it‚Äôs even covered by top-tier consulting companies and even by UN that‚Äôs how good the program is 

And then there‚Äôs also investment incentives for industries to receive Indonesian workers, and even foreign companies has to be mandated that they have to have a certain amount of percentage in of Indonesian working with them, and if it reaches above those minimum requirements, they even get tax incentives 

In the long-term, there are studies or even programs like merdeka belajar which is an excellent program

Author: unknownblue
Content:

Author: unknownblue
Content:
But why the fuck is there still so many unemployed people and brain drain

What Indonesia lacks as a whole isn‚Äôt exactly education isn‚Äôt exactly policy revolving providing work or employment opportunities 


Indonesia, as a country lacks supporting infrastructure to ensure our citizen have good job jobs and good living 

See it‚Äôs not about having a job and it‚Äôs not about being part of the job market 

It‚Äôs about having a good life and that‚Äôs what Indonesian government lacks

Author: unknownblue
Content:
If you get a job in Indonesia and you have your savings, could you buy a house?

If you work really hard in Indonesia and then you‚Äôre sick, would you be covered? 

If you work alone as the head of a family and you support your family with your pay 

If you studied really hard on some esoteric major that‚Äôs not exactly well implemented Indonesia 
Were you taught how to creatively implement those knowledge that you have?
